sn22.85:4.1: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn22.85:4.2: Now at that time a mendicant called Yamaka had the following harmful misconception:
sn22.85:4.3: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.”
sn22.85:5.1: A number of mendicants heard about this.
sn22.85:5.5: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side
sn22.85:6.1: “Is it really true, Reverend Yamaka, that you have such a harmful misconception:
sn22.85:6.2: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.’”
sn22.85:6.3: “Yes, reverends, that’s how I understand the Buddha’s teaching.”
sn22.85:7.1: “Don’t say that, Yamaka! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.”
sn22.85:7.5: But even though admonished by those mendicants, Yamaka obstinately held on to that misconception and insisted on stating it.
sn22.85:8.1: When those mendicants were unable to dissuade Yamaka from that misconception, they got up from their seats and went to see Venerable Sāriputta.
sn22.85:8.2: They told him what had happened, and said:
sn22.85:8.5: “May Venerable Sāriputta please go to the mendicant Yamaka out of compassion.”
sn22.85:8.7: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of solitude, went to Venerable Yamaka
sn22.85:8.9: Seated to one side he said to Yamaka:
sn22.85:9.1: “Is it really true, Reverend Yamaka, that you have such a harmful misconception:
sn22.85:9.2: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.’”
sn22.85:9.3: “Yes, reverend, that’s how I understand the Buddha’s teaching.”
sn22.85:10.1: “What do you think, Yamaka? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn22.85:10.10: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’
sn22.85:11.1: What do you think, Reverend Yamaka? Do you regard the Realized One as form?”
sn22.85:11.3: “Do you regard the Realized One as feeling …
sn22.85:12.1: “What do you think, Reverend Yamaka? Do you regard the Realized One as in form?”
sn22.85:12.3: “Or do you regard the Realized One as distinct from form?”
sn22.85:12.5: “Do you regard the realized one as in feeling …
sn22.85:12.13: “Or do you regard the Realized One as distinct from consciousness?”
sn22.85:13.1: “What do you think, Yamaka? Do you regard the Realized One as possessing form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
sn22.85:14.1: “What do you think, Yamaka? Do you regard the Realized One as one who is without form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
sn22.85:14.7: “In that case, Reverend Yamaka, since you don’t acknowledge the Realized One as a genuine fact in the present life, is it appropriate to declare:
sn22.85:14.8: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.’?”
sn22.85:15.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, in my ignorance, I used to have that misconception.
sn22.85:15.2: But now that I’ve heard the teaching from Venerable Sāriputta I’ve given up that misconception, and I’ve comprehended the teaching.”
sn22.85:16.1: “Reverend Yamaka, suppose they were to ask you:
sn22.85:16.2: ‘When their body breaks up, after death, what happens to a perfected one, who has ended the defilements?’
sn22.85:16.4: “Sir, if they were to ask this,
sn22.85:16.9: What’s suffering has ceased and ended.
sn22.85:16.15: What’s suffering has ceased and ended.’
sn22.85:16.16: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”
sn22.85:17.2: Well then, I shall give you a simile to make the meaning even clearer.
sn22.85:17.3: Suppose there was a householder or householder’s son who was rich, with a lot of money and great wealth,
sn22.85:17.5: Then along comes a person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten him, and take his life.
sn22.85:17.7: ‘This householder or householder’s son is rich, with a lot of money and great wealth,
sn22.85:17.9: It won’t be easy to take his life by force.
sn22.85:17.10: Why don’t I get close to him, then take his life?’
sn22.85:17.11: So he goes up to that householder or householder’s son and says:
sn22.85:17.13: Then they would serve that householder or householder’s son.
sn22.85:17.14: They’d get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking kindly.
sn22.85:17.15: The householder or householder’s son would consider them as a friend
sn22.85:17.18: But when that person realizes that
sn22.85:17.19: they’ve gained the trust of the householder or householder’s son, then, when they know he’s alone, they’d take his life with a sharp knife.
sn22.85:18.1: What do you think, Yamaka? When that person went to the householder or householder’s son and offered to
sn22.85:18.2: serve him, weren’t they a killer then,
sn22.85:18.5: And when they got up before him and went to bed after him, being obliging, behaving nicely and speaking kindly, weren’t they a killer then,
sn22.85:18.8: And when, knowing he’s alone, they took his life with a sharp knife, weren’t they a killer then,
sn22.85:18.12: “In the same way, an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in their teaching. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in their teaching. They regard form as self, self as having form,
sn22.85:18.13: form in self, or self in form.
sn22.85:18.17: They regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness,
sn22.85:18.18: consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
sn22.85:19.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is impermanent—as impermanent.
sn22.85:20.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is suffering—as suffering.
sn22.85:21.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is not-self—as not-self.
sn22.85:22.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is conditioned—as conditioned.
sn22.85:23.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is a killer—as a killer.
sn22.85:23.5: consciousness—which is a killer—as a killer.
sn22.85:24.1: They’re attracted to form, grasp it, and commit to the notion that it’s ‘my self’.

sn22.85:27.1: They truly understand form—which is suffering—as suffering.
sn22.85:28.1: They truly understand form—which is not-self—as not-self.
sn22.85:29.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is conditioned—as conditioned.

sn22.85:31.1: Not being attracted to form, they don’t grasp it, and commit to the notion that it’s ‘my self’.

sn22.85:31.8: And when you’re not attracted to and don’t grasp these five grasping aggregates, they lead to your lasting welfare and happiness.”
sn22.85:31.9: “Reverend Sāriputta, this is how it is when you have such venerables as spiritual companions to advise and instruct you out of kindness and compassion.
sn22.85:31.10: And after hearing this teaching by Venerable Sāriputta, my mind is freed from the defilements without grasping.”
